output.en: âœ… This is a legitimate message from the Singapore Police Force. It reminds users that silent or accidental calls to '999' are an offence and can impede emergency services. SMS '70999' is an official alternative for emergencies when you cannot speak. Misuse of emergency numbers is punishable by law. Always avoid unintended emergency calls to help keep resources available for real emergencies.

report.en:
The message is a legitimate communication from the Singapore Police Force (SPF) regarding silent calls to the emergency number '999'. It informs the recipient that a silent call was received from their number and advises them to call '999' again or SMS '70999' if there is a genuine police emergency. The message also warns that making silent calls to '999' is an offence and may lead to prosecution, as such calls impede the SPF from performing its duties and may put lives at risk.

The SMS number '70999' is confirmed as an official SMS text messaging platform by the Singapore Police Force for emergency assistance when it is unsafe to call '999' or when the caller cannot speak. This service is provided at no cost to users, though normal SMS rates apply.

Further verification from official SPF sources highlights that misuse of the emergency number '999', including silent or hoax calls, is taken seriously and is punishable under Singapore law. Such misuse causes delays in response to genuine emergencies and wastes police resources. The penalties for making harassing or obscene calls to emergency numbers can include imprisonment and fines.

In conclusion, the message is authentic and serves as an important reminder to avoid accidental or intentional silent calls to '999'. The use of SMS '70999' is a legitimate alternative for emergencies where speaking is not possible. Users should heed the advice to prevent unintended emergency calls and understand the legal consequences of misuse.

communityNote.en: âœ… This is a legitimate message from the Singapore Police Force. It reminds users that silent or accidental calls to '999' are an offence and can impede emergency services. SMS '70999' is an official alternative for emergencies when you cannot speak. Misuse of emergency numbers is punishable by law. Always avoid unintended emergency calls to help keep resources available for real emergencies.

result.title: SMS claiming to be from Singapore Police

vars.production_output: ğŸš¨ This is likely a scam. The message claims to be from "POLICE 999" about a silent call, but it contains red flags. "POLICE 999" is not a standard sender ID, and '70999' is not a recognized emergency number in Singapore. The "Not Delivered" status further suggests it's not legitimate. Ignore such messages and contact '999' directly for emergencies.
vars.expert_golden_answer: ğŸŸ¢This is legitimate. The SMS number 70999 is an official emergency contact provided by the Singapore Police Force (SPF). It is intended for situations where it is unsafe or impossible to make a voice call to '999', such as during hostage situations or when the caller has speech or hearing impairments. The SPF's official website confirms that SMS 70999 is a legitimate service for requesting emergency assistance via text.
vars.expert_pointers:
- Should identify 70999 as a legitimate phone number
- Should explain what 70999 is for
- Should cite the official police website and show it in sources
- Should say that if it's an alphanumeric sender ID it is likely to be legitimate

output.en: ğŸš¨ This is a scam. The message impersonates Apple Genius Bar and includes a suspicious link and unverified phone number. Apple does not send SMS with diagnostic links or request replies to reschedule via SMS. Do not click the link or respondâ€”delete the message to protect your personal information and device security.

report.en:
The message claims to hold a place in line at the Apple Genius Bar and asks the recipient to run diagnostics via a suspicious link ("diags://..."). It also provides options to cancel or reschedule the appointment by replying with numbers. 

Analysis of search results indicates that similar messages have been reported as scams or phishing attempts impersonating Apple support. Apple does not typically send such SMS messages with diagnostic links or ask for replies to reschedule via SMS. The link format "diags://" is not a recognized or legitimate Apple URL scheme. Additionally, the phone number used is not verified as an official Apple contact number.

Users are advised not to click on the link or reply to the message, as it may lead to phishing or malware risks. Official Apple Genius Bar communications usually come through the Apple Support app, official Apple emails, or verified Apple phone numbers.

Conclusion: The SMS message is very likely a scam or phishing attempt impersonating Apple Genius Bar support. It should be ignored and deleted to avoid potential security risks.

Sources include Apple community discussions, scam alert pages, and official Apple support guidelines.

communityNote.en: ğŸš¨ This is a scam. The message impersonates Apple Genius Bar and includes a suspicious link and unverified phone number. Apple does not send SMS with diagnostic links or request replies to reschedule via SMS. Do not click the link or respondâ€”delete the message to protect your personal information and device security.

It includes queue updates, instructions, and a diagnostic link (diags://), which is a standard Apple tool used during support sessions. If you werenâ€™t expecting this, donâ€™t click the linkâ€”otherwise, itâ€™s safe to proceed.

- Should confirm that the message format is consistent with Appleâ€™s standard support communications
- Should advise users not to click the link if they werenâ€™t expecting the message
- Should explain that the diagnostic link (diags://) is a standard Apple tool

output.en: âŒ This is largely untrue. The dates listed for Singapore's 2025 General Election do not match official sources. The correct dates are: Nomination Day on 23 April 2025, Election Campaign from 24 April to 1 May 2025, Cooling-off Day on 2 May 2025, and Voting Day on 3 May 2025. Always refer to the Elections Department Singapore (eld.gov.sg) for accurate information.

report.en:
The content lists key dates related to the Singapore 2025 General Election: Nomination Day on 28 April 2025, Election Campaign from 2 May to 8 May 2025, Cooling-off Day on 9 May 2025, and Voting Day on 10 May 2025. However, official and credible sources including the Elections Department Singapore (ELD) and multiple news outlets confirm different dates for the 2025 General Election cycle. The official Nomination Day was on 23 April 2025, the Election Campaign period started immediately after Nomination Day, the Cooling-off Day was on 2 May 2025, and the Voting Day was on 3 May 2025. These dates are consistent across government releases and reputable news sources.

Therefore, the dates provided in the content are inaccurate and do not align with the official election timeline for Singapore's 2025 General Election. The official dates are:
- Nomination Day: 23 April 2025
- Election Campaign: 24 April to 1 May 2025
- Cooling-off Day: 2 May 2025
- Voting Day: 3 May 2025

Users should rely on official sources such as the Elections Department Singapore (eld.gov.sg) for accurate election information to avoid confusion or misinformation.

communityNote.en: âŒ This is largely untrue. The dates listed for Singapore's 2025 General Election do not match official sources. The correct dates are: Nomination Day on 23 April 2025, Election Campaign from 24 April to 1 May 2025, Cooling-off Day on 2 May 2025, and Voting Day on 3 May 2025. Always refer to the Elections Department Singapore (eld.gov.sg) for accurate information.

Election Campaign 2/5-8/5/25
Cooling-off Day 9/5/25
Voting Day 10/5/25

componentResults.reason: The reply correctly identifies that the $10,000 premium applies to SC-PR households and cites official HDB policies but fails to clarify that it is not exclusive to first-generation citizens, does not rate the message as misleading, does not include the correct HDB webpage as a source, and omits information about the Citizen Top Up scheme.

prompt.raw: [The source text is not provided, but for context, it is a submission to CheckMate, an information verification service in Singapore. It is either a text message, an image (optionally with a caption), or a link.]
prompt.label: [The source text is not provided, but for context, it is a submission to CheckMate, an information verification service in Singapore. It is either a text message, an image (optionally with a caption), or a link.]

output.en: âœ… This is largely true. Singapore Citizen-PR households applying for HDB BTO flats must pay a $10,000 premium, as stated in official HDB policies. This rule applies when one applicant is a Singapore Citizen and the other is a Permanent Resident. The information is accurate and confirmed by multiple official and reputable sources.

report.en:
The claim states that first generation Singapore citizens applying for HDB BTO flats with Singapore Permanent Residents (PRs) need to pay a premium of $10,000. Official information from the Housing & Development Board (HDB) of Singapore and reputable property guides confirm this.

For households comprising one Singapore Citizen and one or more Singapore Permanent Residents, a premium of $10,000 is required in addition to the flat price. This is a recognized policy to differentiate between households with only Singapore Citizens and those with PRs. This premium is documented in multiple official HDB annexes and property guides, which are legitimate and up-to-date sources.

The $10,000 premium applies specifically to couples or families where one party is a Singapore Citizen and the other is a PR. This is consistent across various official documents and property advisory sites.

Conclusion: The information about the $10,000 premium for first generation Singapore citizens applying with Singapore Permanent Residents for HDB BTO flats is accurate and legitimate, based on official HDB policies and credible property sources in Singapore.

communityNote.en: âœ… This is largely true. Singapore Citizen-PR households applying for HDB BTO flats must pay a $10,000 premium, as stated in official HDB policies. This rule applies when one applicant is a Singapore Citizen and the other is a Permanent Resident. The information is accurate and confirmed by multiple official and reputable sources.

result.text: First Generation Singapore citizens that are applying with Singapore Permanent Residents need to pay premium for HDB BTO flats $10,000
result.title: Claim about HDB BTO premium payment

vars.input_text: First Generation Singapore citizens that are applying with Singapore Permanent Residents need to pay premium for HDB BTO flats $10,000
vars.production_output: âœ… This is largely true. First-generation Singapore citizens applying for HDB BTO flats with Singapore Permanent Residents must pay a $10,000 premium. This is part of the Citizen Top-Up scheme, which applies to households with one Singapore Citizen and at least one PR. The premium is required when purchasing a new BTO flat.
vars.expert_pointers:
- It should state that it while it is true that first-time households that comprise a Singapore Citizen and an SPR will need to pay a premium of $10,000 at flat purchase, this does not apply to first-generation Singaporeans only, but all Singaporeans
- As such, it should give the message a misleading rating
- It should cite the right HDB website as a source (https://www.hdb.gov.sg/residential/buying-a-flat/understanding-your-eligibility-and-housing-loan-options/flat-and-grant-eligibility/couples-and-families)
- It should be helpful and explain that after the SPR gains Singapore citizenship, or if the couple have a child who is a Singapore citizen, they can apply for the Citizen Top Up scheme to reimburse this premium. If it does this, it should cite the right source (https://www.hdb.gov.sg/residential/servicing-your-hdb-housing-loan/citizen-topup)
